✔ REVISION – PART 1: Basics of Software Testing
What is Software Testing? Explain in simple words.
What is the difference between Verification and Validation?
What is the difference between Severity and Priority?

Q 1. What is Software Testing? Explain in simple words ans. software testing is a process to ensure the software are defects or bug free before relase and its meet as per clint requrment. Q 2. What is the difference between Verification and Validation? ans. verification and validion are both is a step of software testing in this verification is verify the requirement ans condition of the clint before start to built software and validation is check what we build meets as per clint requrtement verification = what to be build validation = what we build. Q 3. What is the difference between Severity and Priority? ans . severity means how much big is problem priority mean how much important is problem
Great work, Shubham! Your answers are correct, but let me refine them into interview-ready versions and point out small improvements.

Software testing is the process of checking whether the software works correctly, is free from defects, and meets the client’s requirements before release. The goal is to ensure quality and prevent issues for users.
Verification ensures we are building the product correctly. It checks requirements, documents, and plans before development.
Validation ensures we built the correct product. It checks the final software after development to see if it meets customer requirements.
✔ Verification → Are we building it right?
✔ Validation → Are we building the right thing?
Your answer: Correct but you can expand
Severity → How serious the defect is from a technical point of view.
Priority → How soon the defect needs to be fixed.
Spelling mistake on homepage → Low Severity but High Priority (because many users will see it).
Now we move to next section: SDLC & STLC.
What is SDLC? Name any two SDLC models.
What is STLC? Explain the phases in short.
Is Waterfall and SDLC same? Explain.
Answer these three questions. I’ll check them and guide you to the next topic.

Q 4. What is SDLC? Name any two SDLC models. Ans . Ans. waterfall and SDLC both are diffrent wahre waterfall used in small project and in this clint can not change their reqirment once deal done and SDLC use in high or big project and in SDLC we change as per clint requrment and SDLC is used for all project
Great effort, Shubham! Your concepts are mostly correct—just need some polishing for interview-ready clarity. Let’s refine each answer.
✅ Q4. What is SDLC? Name any two SDLC models.
SDLC stands for Software Development Life Cycle.
It is a process followed by software companies to plan, design, develop, test, and deliver high-quality software.
❗ Q5. What is STLC? Explain the phases in short.
STLC stands for Software Testing Life Cycle.
It defines the steps followed by testers to ensure software quality.
1. Requirement Analysis – understand what needs to be tested
2. Test Planning – create test strategy, effort estimation
3. Test Case Design – write test cases/test scenarios
8. Test Closure – report summary, close activities
⚠️ Q6. Is Waterfall and SDLC same? Explain.
✔ You know they are different, but explanation needs correction.
No, Waterfall is not the same as SDLC.
SDLC is the overall process of developing software (planning → design → development → testing → deployment).
Waterfall is one SDLC model, meaning one way to follow the SDLC steps.
In Waterfall, requirements cannot change easily.
It is used for small or well-defined projects.
Agile is used where changes happen frequently.
“SDLC is the complete development process. Waterfall is just one model of SDLC.”
What is the difference between Functional Testing and Non-Functional Testing?
Answer these, and I will correct + teach you the next topic.

What is Regression Testing Ans . regression testing is the modifyd part and after any changes of the software to test hole projct after modifying any fuction or fixing ang bug to check does t effct software Q 9. What is the difference between Functional Testing and Non-Functional Testing? Ans . Non functional testing is test the software like timeing and security and behavior, envorment and fuctional testing is unit testing and integration and UAT(user acceptance testin)
Great work Shubham! Your understanding is good, just needs polishing for interview-ready clarity. Let’s refine each answer.
Smoke Testing is a quick basic test done after receiving a new build to check whether the critical and major functionalities of the application are working or not.
If smoke testing fails → the build is rejected and not tested further.
➡️ “Is the build stable enough for testing?”
✔ Your concept: Correct but needs clearer explanation.
Regression testing is performed after any change in the application—such as bug fixes, new features, or code updates—to make sure that the existing working features are not broken.
➡️ Check old functionality after new change
Your answer has correct keywords, but needs structure.
➡️ Tests quality attributes of the software

Q 10. What is a Bug/Defect? Ans . in project if any functionality is not match as per clint or getting error in any functionaly is called bug or defect Q 11. Explain the Bug Life Cycle. Ans . bug life cycle is process of finding a bug and make a report and fix it and it have several steps like find new bug - assing- fix - retest- closed Q 12.What are the important fields in a Bug Report? (Name at least 5 Ans . in bug report all field are important like 1. test case id, 2. test scenario, 3. test cases, 4. test data, 5. expected resuld
Great effort, Shubham! Your concepts are correct, just need fine-tuning for interview quality. Let me refine them and correct a few misunderstanding points.
A bug/defect is a difference between the expected result and the actual result in the software.
It occurs when the software does not behave as per the client requirement or gives an incorrect output.
⚠️ Q11. Explain the Bug Life Cycle.
Your answer has the right idea, but the steps are incomplete.
1. New – Tester finds a bug and logs it
2. Assigned – Lead/manager assigns bug to developer
3. Open – Developer starts working on the bug
5. Retest – Tester checks the bug again
7. Closed – If bug is fixed successfully
8. Deferred/Rejected (optional) – Bug is not taken for now or not valid
Your version was close but now it’s complete.
❗ Q12. Important fields in a Bug Report
Your answer listed test case fields, not bug report fields.
These will be asked in interviews very often.
⭐ You are doing excellent, and your learning is fast!

Great job, Shubham! Your answers are correct in concept — now I’ll polish them into interview-ready responses and fill small gaps.
✅ Q13. What is a Test Case? Explain with an example.
A test case is a document that contains steps, test data, expected result, and actual result used to verify a specific functionality of the software.
Example: Test Case for Valid Login
Expected Result: User should successfully log in to the dashboard.
This is a perfect crisp answer for interviews.
✅ Q14. What is a Test Scenario? Give one example.
A test scenario is a high-level description of what to test. It covers one complete functionality.
“Verify login functionality with valid and invalid credentials.”
✅ Q15. Difference between Test Case and Test Scenario

Q 16. What is Sanity Testing? Ans . Sanity testing is one the populaor testing it is done after build the softeware and any chenges in software to check after the changes software are bug/defect free and work as per requrment Q 17.What is User Acceptance Testing (UAT)? Ans . User acceptance testing is test after software are build and all test done to check software meets as per user requrment and as per document Q 18. Explain Black Box Testing. Ans . back box testing is one of the testing models and it test by tester and in black box tesing test only software scalability , durability and security and its performance and timeing
Great effort, Shubham! Your answers show strong understanding. Let’s refine them into perfect interview-quality answers and correct one misunderstanding in Q18.
✔ Your concept is correct, just refine it.
Sanity testing is a quick testing performed after getting a new build or after small changes (bug fixes) to check whether the newly added functionality or bug fix is working correctly.
If sanity testing fails → the build is rejected for further testing.
➡️ Sanity = Check small change works properly
✅ Q17. What is User Acceptance Testing (UAT)?
User Acceptance Testing (UAT) is the final testing done by the client or end users to check whether the software meets their business requirements and is ready for real-world use.
➡️ If client says “Yes, everything is correct,” the product goes live.
Your answer mixed up non-functional testing. Black box testing is mainly functional testing.
Black Box Testing is a testing technique where the tester does not look at the internal code.
The tester checks the application only based on inputs and expected outputs.
Examples of what is tested in Black Box Testing:
➡️ Tester doesn’t know how the system is built internally — only tests functionality.

Since you have completed all revision topics till now, we’ll move to Agile step-by-step and study it clearly LIKE AN INTERVIEW + LIKE A REAL WORKPLACE.
I’ll explain each concept simply, then ask you questions so you remember them properly.
Agile is a project methodology where software is developed in small parts (iterations) and delivered quickly to the client.
Work is divided into small cycles called Sprints
Changes are accepted even in the middle of the project
Scrum is the most popular Agile framework.
Makes sure everyone follows Agile process
Team plans the work for the next sprint.
Team demos the completed work to Product Owner / Client.
Internal meeting: What went well? What can be improved?

Your Agile concepts are good, but let’s correct and refine them to interview-level accuracy, especially Q22.

Agile methodology is an approach where software is developed and delivered in small parts (iterations). The client can review and test each part early, give feedback, and changes are accepted anytime during the development. It focuses on speed, continuous testing, and flexibility.
Your answer is half correct but incomplete.
A Sprint is a fixed time period (usually 1–4 weeks) in Agile where the team develops and tests a set of user stories.
It is a mini-project inside Agile.
➡️ Sprint = Timebox where actual development & testing happens.
You answered Tester, but this is incorrect.
User Stories are written by the Product Owner (PO).
Testers can help or give suggestions, but the actual writing responsibility is of:

Q 23 . What is an API in simple words? Ans . API stand for application programing interface and use itract or transfer data to server or one application to other it is a way of transmiteing data . Q 24 .What is API Testing? Ans . a api testing is a process of test to data are transmitng to server or each other without any traffic and malware checking attack
Your concepts are correct — just need to polish them into clear, interview-ready definitions and correct a few small mistakes.
✅ Q23. What is an API in simple words?
API (Application Programming Interface) is a way for two software systems to communicate and exchange data.
It allows applications to send and receive information from a server.
➡️ API is like a messenger that carries data between apps and servers.
Your idea is correct, but wording needs improvement (we don’t mention malware or traffic in API testing).
API Testing is the process of testing an API to check:
If it returns the correct data
If it responds with the correct status codes
If it works fast and without errors
If the API is reliable and secure
➡️ In API testing, we validate request → response.
⭐ Now I will teach you API Testing step-by-step (VERY IMPORTANT FOR INTERVIEW)
We test APIs using tools like Postman.
3. What Do Testers Check in API Testing?

Q 25 . 5: What is the difference between GET and POST? Ans . GET = used get data from usere POST = used create new user Q 26 .What does Status Code 200 mean? Ans . 200= ok (request successfull) Q 27 . When do we use PUT in API? Ans . PUT = used to update existing data
All three answers are correct. I’ll give you the interview-ready polished versions (simple + perfect), then we’ll move to SQL.
✅ Q25. Difference between GET and POST
GET → Used to retrieve data from the server
POST → Used to create new data on the server
✅ Q26. What does Status Code 200 mean?
200 OK means the request was successful and the server returned the expected response.
✅ Q27. When do we use PUT in API?
PUT is used to update existing data completely in the server.

It is the blueprint of the entire testing process.

Conditions that must be completed before testing can start.
Conditions that must be completed before testing can stop.

✅ Login — 5 Test Scenarios (copy these rows into your Excel)
Test Scenario: Verify login with valid email and password
Description: Check that a registered user can log in using a valid email and correct password and is redirected to the homepage.
Test Scenario: Verify login with invalid password
Description: Enter a registered email with a wrong password and verify an appropriate error message is displayed (e.g., “Your password is incorrect”).
Test Scenario: Verify login with unregistered email
Description: Enter an email that is not registered and any password; verify the system shows a message (e.g., “Account not found” / suggest signup).
Test Scenario: Verify login with empty email and/or password fields
Description: Leave email and/or password blank and click Login; verify validation messages appear asking to fill required fields.
Test Scenario: Verify “Forgot Password” flow navigation
Description: Click “Forgot Password” link from login page and verify user is navigated to the password recovery page and receives reset instructions.

⭐ STEP 4 — Add to Cart Module (5 Test Scenarios)
Copy these into your Excel under your existing columns.
Test Scenario: Verify adding a product to the cart
Description: Select a product and click “Add to Cart”; verify item is added successfully.
Test Scenario: Verify updating quantity in cart
Description: Change item quantity (1 → 2 or 2 → 1) and verify cart updates price and quantity correctly.
Test Scenario: Verify removing a product from cart
Description: Remove an item from cart and verify the cart gets updated.
Test Scenario: Verify cart price calculation
Description: Ensure item price × quantity = total price; including delivery charges if applicable.
Test Scenario: Verify user cannot checkout without login
Description: Try checkout without logging in; verify user is asked to sign in first.
